title: Tapinocaninus
text:
Tapinocaninus is an <a href="extinct">extinct</a> <a href="genus">genus</a> of <a href="therapsids">therapsids</a> in the family <a href="Tapinocephalidae">Tapinocephalidae</a>, of which it is the most basal member. Only one species is known, "Tapinocaninus pamelae" (meaning "Pam's humble canine"). Fossils have been found dating from the <a href="Guadalupian">Middle Permian</a> (<a href="Wordian">Wordian</a> age).
Description.
It grew up to long, and massed up to . It is assumed to be either a herbivore or an omnivore. This dinocephalian has a heterodont dentition, consisting of incisors, canines and postcanines. It's canine teeth lack a definite crushing heel. The maxillary and premaxillary dentition is only partially preserved.
The species is named in honour of Rubidge's mother.
Discovery.
Fossils have been found in the <a href="Eodicynodon%20Assemblage%20Zone">Eodicynodon Assemblage Zone</a> of the Karoo deposits, in the Lower Beaufort Beds in Beaufort West, by the director of the BPI, Professor Bruce Rubidge. Four specimens are known. A holotype (NMQR 2987) and three paratypes (NMQR 2985, 2986 and ROZ K95). All of them are known from skull and mandible bones.
